repnme.cdata!:
Colombia - Cartagena Water Supply, Sewerage
            and Environmental Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Cartagena Water Supply,
            Sewerage and Environmental Management Project for Colombia
            were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Lessons learned include: the Bank strategy to
            continue supporting ACUACAR (Aguas de Cartagena - the water
            and sewerage company of Cartagena) through the project was
            instrumental to consolidate the sector reform initiated in
            Cartagena under a previous Bank operation, and to establish
            the needed credibility of the mixed enterprise model.
            ACUACAR's notable improvements in the quality and
            access of water and sewerage provision coupled with
            providing wastewater treatment and adequate disposal have
            significantly increased the well being of the population.
            Providing wastewater collection, treatment and disposal to a
            large urban city in a developing country is a complex and
            challenging endeavor requiring careful design and technical
            expertise to provide an adequate wastewater management
            system using a strategy of minimum cost that considers
            financial and economic limitations, but is also protective
            of the environment. Even through the project was well
            prepared technically; implementation took over a decade due
            to complications in obtaining the environmental license,
            local opposition to the outfall solution. Complex projects
            should include inclusive and extensive consultations with
            stakeholders to explain objectives, design, approach and
            benefits. A comprehensive communication strategy, to create
            a better understanding of the project and dissipate
            erroneous information, and promised activities that benefit
            the affected population should be conducted at an early
            stage during project implementation. The mixed enterprise
            ACUACAR model has proved to have a dramatic impact on the
            lives of the poor in Cartagena. The resources for expanding
            coverage in poor areas were generated mainly from efficiency
            improvements and subsidies, with only minor increases in tariffs.

repnme.cdata!:
Colombia - Cartegena Water Supply, Sewerage
            and Environmental Management Project : Inspection Panel -
            progress report

abstracts.cdata!:
On July 29, 2005, Management submitted
            its Report and Recommendations in response to the Inspection
            Panel's Investigation Report of June 24, 2005
            No.32034-CO on the Cartagena Water Supply, Sewerage and
            Environmental Management Project. On November 8, 2005, the
            Board discussed the Inspection Panel Investigation Report
            and Management's Report and Recommendations in Response
            to the Investigation Report. The Board endorsed the Action
            Plan proposed by Management as an adequate response to the
            Inspection Panel's findings, requested to proceed with
            project implementation while implementing, in parallel, the
            proposed Action Plan, and asked that Management report back
            on the progress in implementing this Action Plan. The
            present report is aimed at providing information to the
            Board regarding the progress in implementing the Action Plan
            proposed by Management, and the discussions with the
            Inspection Panel regarding three dimensional modeling.

repnme.cdata!:
Colombia - Cartagena Water Supply and
            Sewerage and Environmental Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This report examines the merits of the
            claims presented in the Request and Management's
            Response to the claims. In chapter 2, environmental
            compliance is discussed; chapter 3, deals with social
            compliance; chapter 4, discusses economic compliance; and
            chapter 5, assess financial compliance and supervision. This
            report concludes the Panel's investigation into the
            matters alleged in the Request for Inspection. The Panel
            notes the urgent need for Cartagena to have in place a
            sustainable system for disposing of its wastes. This is
            especially essential when the population of the city is
            growing rapidly. The Panel hopes that its Report will be of
            value in assessing Bank's compliance with its policies
            and procedures and in furthering the development of a
            sustainable and equitable waste disposal system.

repnme.cdata!:
Colombia - Bogota Urban Transport Project;
            Antioquia Education Project; Cartagena Water Supply,
            Sewerage and Environmental Management Project - proposed
            amendment to the loan agreement

abstracts.cdata!:
The proposed amendment to the Loan
            Agreement will provide the department of Antioquia, the
            municipality of Bogota and the municipality of Cartagena,
            and the Republic of Colombia with access to IBRD's
            financial products for the purpose of managing the interest
            rate and currency exposure they currently have as a result
            of their US Dollar-denominated variable spread loans (VSL).
            The proposed amendments will allow the Borrowers to: (i)
            convert the currency of denomination of the loans; (ii)
            change the interest rate basis of the loans from floating
            rate to fixed rate and vice versa; and (iii) place a cap or
            a collar on the interest rate applicable to the loans.

repnme.cdata!:
Colombia - Cartagena Water Supply and
            Sewerage and Environmental Management Project : Resettlement Plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The Cartagena Water Supply and Sewerage
            and Environmental Management Project will: (i) improve the
            water and sewerage services of Cartagena and the sanitary
            conditions of the city's poorest population, by
            expanding water and sewerage coverage, particularly in the
            city's poor neighborhoods, (ii) facilitate the
            environmental cleanup of water bodies surrounding the city
            (Cartagena Bay, Caribbean beaches and Cienaga de la Virgen
            lake) by providing adequate collection, treatment and
            disposal of the entire flow of the city's wastewater;
            and (iii) improve the sustainability of water and sewerage
            services in Cartagena. The resettlement plan indicates that
            No involuntary resettlement is expected to take place as a
            result of the construction of any component of the
            facilities to be financed by the project.

TF029605-PHRD-CARTAGENA WATER SUPPLY,
            SEWERAGE AND,TF035447-LAC REGION - WASTE WATER

repnme.cdata!:
Local solutions improve water supply and
            sanitation services in Colombia

abstracts.cdata!:
The government of Colombia has been a
            pioneer in adopting sound water sector policies. It was
            among the forerunners of decentralization. It established a
            legal framework that clearly separates service provision
            from policy making, thus allowing private sector
            participation. The key to success in the Colombian water
            sector reform has been the development of homegrown
            solutions, and at times, skillfully adapting models used
            elsewhere to the particular circumstances and culture of
            Colombia. As a result, Colombia has made substantial
            progress in the expansion of water supply and sanitation
            (WSS) services. By 2002, urban water supply access was 99
            percent, rural water supply coverage 71 percent. Sanitation
            access has also been upgraded with urban coverage of 96
            percent and rural coverage of 54 percent. Over the years,
            the World Bank has supported Colombia through advisory work,
            capacity building and lending. Since 1988, the World Bank
            has provided a series of loans with a total value of over
            US$ 700 million to the Colombian WSS sector.

docna.cdata!:
Local solutions improve water supply and
            sanitation services in Colombia

Local solutions improve water
            supply and sanitation services in Colombia

repnme.cdata!:
Colombia - Cartagena Water Supply and
            Sewerage and Environmental Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This report, is in response to the
            findings of the Inspection Panel (report 32034) and includes
            Management's Action Plan, it is organized in several
            sections. Section 2, briefly describes the Project and
            provides an update on Project status. Section 3, summarizes
            the findings and observations of the Panel. Section 4,
            provides additional background information on several key
            issues. Section 5, presents the Action Plan and Section 6,
            contains the conclusion. A detailed matrix containing the
            Panel's findings, along with Management's
            responses, is provided in Annex 1. Annexes 2-4 contain
            supporting materials. Conclusion, in Management's view,
            the Bank has made every effort to apply its policies and
            procedures and to pursue its mission statement in the
            context of the Project. It is Management's judgment
            that the proposed Action Plan appropriately addresses the
            issues identified in the Panel's report. In regard to
            poverty alleviation, Management shares the Panel's
            views on the importance of the Project's poverty
            related impacts on Cartagena's poor and vulnerable population.

docna.cdata!:
Management report and recommendation in
            response to the Inspection Panel investigation report

            and Sewerage and Environmental Management Project :
            Management report and recommendation in response to the

            agua, alcantarillado y ordenamiento ambiental de Cartagena

repnme.cdata!:
Colombia - Cartagena Water Supply and
            Sewerage and Environmental Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This report, is in response to the
            findings of the Inspection Panel (report 32034) and includes
            Management's Action Plan, it is organized in several
            sections. Section 2, briefly describes the Project and
            provides an update on Project status. Section 3, summarizes
            the findings and observations of the Panel. Section 4,
            provides additional background information on several key
            issues. Section 5, presents the Action Plan and Section 6,
            contains the conclusion. A detailed matrix containing the
            Panel's findings, along with Management's
            responses, is provided in Annex 1. Annexes 2-4 contain
            supporting materials. Conclusion, in Management's view,
            the Bank has made every effort to apply its policies and
            procedures and to pursue its mission statement in the
            context of the Project. It is Management's judgment
            that the proposed Action Plan appropriately addresses the
            issues identified in the Panel's report. In regard to
            poverty alleviation, Management shares the Panel's
            views on the importance of the Project's poverty
            related impacts on Cartagena's poor and vulnerable population.

repnme.cdata!:
Colombia - Cartagena Water Supply and
            Sewerage and Environmental Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This report examines the merits of the
            claims presented in the Request and Management's
            Response to the claims. In chapter 2, environmental
            compliance is discussed; chapter 3, deals with social
            compliance; chapter 4, discusses economic compliance; and
            chapter 5, assess financial compliance and supervision. This
            report concludes the Panel's investigation into the
            matters alleged in the Request for Inspection. The Panel
            notes the urgent need for Cartagena to have in place a
            sustainable system for disposing of its wastes. This is
            especially essential when the population of the city is
            growing rapidly. The Panel hopes that its Report will be of
            value in assessing Bank's compliance with its policies
            and procedures and in furthering the development of a
            sustainable and equitable waste disposal system.

            and Sewerage and Environmental Management Project : The
            Inspection Panel, investigation report
